item.title: WEEK 12: Prosocial Behavior
item.description: Study materials: Reading material: DOWNLOAD Homework assignment: No homework assignment. Lecture summary: The lecture on prosocial behavior begins by defining it as any act intended to benefit another person. Altruism is described as helping others even at a cost to oneself. Evolutionary psychology suggests that prosocial behavior, especially towards genetic relatives, is favored by natural selection. The norm of reciprocity indicates that helping others increases the likelihood of future help. Social exchange theory posits that people help when the benefits outweigh the costs, suggesting true altruism may not exist.

Lecture summary: Prejudice is defined as a hostile or negative attitude towards individuals based on their membership in a particular group. It comprises cognitive, affective, and behavioral components. The cognitive component involves categorization, where people are grouped based on certain characteristics, leading to stereotypesâ€”generalizations that assign traits to all members of a group.

item.description: Study materials: Reading material: DOWNLOAD Homework assignment: You can access and submit your assignment at the following LINK. Each assignment has a deadline. Once the deadline has passed, the system will no longer accept any additional submissions. Lecture summary: The lecture on conformity and obedience in social psychology explores the mechanisms through which individuals change their behavior due to social influences. Conformity is a change in behavior due to real or imagined influence from others, while obedience involves acting in accord with a direct order.

Lecture summary: A group is defined as two or more individuals who interact and are interdependent, with their needs and goals influencing each other. People join groups to achieve objectives that would be difficult individually, deriving benefits from social identity and norms.

item.description: Study materials: Reading material: DOWNLOAD Homework assignment: You can access and submit your assignment at the following LINK. Each assignment has a deadline. Once the deadline has passed, the system will no longer accept any additional submissions. Lecture summary: Persuasive communication aims to change attitudes and behaviors through targeted messages. Attitude change involves the communicator, the communication, the medium, and the audience’s characteristics. People often think they are less influenced by advertisements than others, known as the third-person effect.

item.title: WEEK 5: Debate
item.description: Dear Students, as I mentioned during the last class, I would like to make a debate on a given subject. Please use some time to prepare, browse the Internet, read some papers and books, and develop your arguments for and against. Question for debate: Does social media use significantly enhance communities and social connectivity or contribute to social isolation and loneliness?

Once the deadline has passed, the system will no longer accept any additional submissions. Lecture summary: Attitudes, complex evaluations of people, objects, and ideas, are influenced by genetics and shaped by social experiences, integrating cognitive, affective, and behavioral components. Cognitive attitudes are based on beliefs about an object’s characteristics, while affective attitudes derive from feelings and values, often influenced by classical and operant conditioning.

Lecture summary: The lecture delved into the contrasting capabilities of machines and humans, highlighting machines’ prowess in calculation games but humans’ superior ability to decipher social nuances. It introduced social cognition, exploring how individuals select, interpret, remember, and utilize social information to make judgments.

Lecture summary: The methodology of Social Psychology employs the scientific method, grounded in epistemology and dedicated to systematic investigation through hypothesis generation, experimentation, and data analysis. This approach distinguishes between science, pseudoscience, and non-science, emphasizing falsifiability as a core principle.
